title: gustar

lessonContent.text: The verb gustar is used to translate the English verb 'to like' and so is very common in Spanish. The important thing to bear in mind right from the outset, however, is that it does not actually mean 'to like', but 'to be pleasing'. In order to say 'I like coffee', what you actually have to say is 'coffee is pleasing to me'. Thus the verb will be in the third person singular, and the 'to me' will be translated by the indirect object pronoun me (seeLesson 11):

words2: I like coffee. (lit. 'Coffee is pleasing to me.')

lessonContent.text: Obviously if the things liked are plural, then a third person plural verb must be used, as the plural noun is the subject of the verb:

words2: I like films. (lit. 'Films are pleasing to me.')

lessonContent.text: The construction can be used with all indirect object pronouns as follows:

words2: Do you like my car? (Is my car pleasing to you?)
He likes to play tennis/playing tennis. (To play tennis is pleasing to him.)
We don't like the biscuits. (The biscuits are not pleasing to us.)
Do you like the idea? (Is the idea pleasing to you?)
They like to skate/they like skating. (To skate is pleasing to them.)

lessonContent.text: If the indirect object is named, it is normally placed at the beginning of the sentence and must be introduced by a, but the pronoun form is also included in the sentences and cannot be omitted:

words1: A Juan le gusta el fútbol.
A mis padres no les gusta la idea.
words2: Juan likes football. (Football is pleasing to Juan.)
My parents don't like the idea. (The idea is not pleasing to my parents.)

lessonContent.text: This construction can cause some difficulty for English speakers and so needs to be studied very carefully.
In colloquial Spanish you will come across the verb gustar being used in other ways, i.e. not only in the third person, for example:

words2: I like you very much/you are very pleasing to me.
He likes me/I am pleasing to him.

lessonContent.text: There are a number of common verbs in Spanish that follow the same pattern as gustar, for example:

words2: I am interested in your opinions. (Your opinions are interesting to me.)
They are delighted by the house. (The house is delightful to them.)
I feel like going out this evening. (It is appealing to me to go out this evening.)
My head hurts/I have a headache.

bTitle: ¿Qué les gusta y no les gusta a los españoles?
bContent: A los españoles les gusta el sol y el buen tiempo, y las vacaciones en las costas españolas son las preferidas por las familias. A los españoles les gusta pasear y después de trabajar las familias suelen salir a “dar una vuelta”, sobre todo en verano cuando hace calor. A los españoles les gusta comer bien y tienen una dieta mediterránea, aunque hay una variedad muy grande de comidas típicas en todas la regiones. A los españoles les gusta tener a la familia cerca y hay mucho contacto entre hermanos, primos, sobrinos, etc.

No a todos los españoles les gustan los toros. Algunos españoles creen que los toros es un pasatiempo cruel y que debe ser prohibido. Tampoco a todos los españoles les gusta el flamenco. El flamenco es sólo típico de Andalucía, las otras regiones de España tienen sus propias tradiciones musicales.
